Mar 31 2009 	Great location but expected more	Booked their suite special 2 nights $450 (1/2 price second night). Although I am aware check-in is at 3pm, my son and I arrived at 10:30am. They told me to check back soon for an available room. I came back at 1:30pm and was sent to what appeared to be the only room available. The stentch of body odor from the prior occupant was so offensive we could not stay in the room. They had the window open to air it out. Not a great first impression. I was then told there was no other room yet, but then after the someone checked with the manager, a new room was available. It was recently renovated so much cleaner and nicer than the first. The hotel location is key to it's appeal. Central Park, museums, restaurants all within walking distance. The major problem I have with the hotel was that I came down with a virus the morning we checked in. It was so bad that I asked my husband the next morning to check with the front desk to see if we could cancel our reservation for that evening (the 2nd night) without penalty as I could barely get out of bed and wanted to go home (we live an hour away). The front desk said no problem. We made it clear that if there was a penalty we would stay (as my husband could have taken my son out while I rested). Upon checkout, they charged us $300 for the one night. We told them we would stay then but they said they already "sold" the room. They indicated I signed upon checkin something that indicated $300 first night, $150 second night (which I knew, which is why we asked if we would not be penalized and pay half of the entire bill or $225). They refused to honor their prior agreement to not penalize us. Although not a really big deal, it did not leave a "good taste" in our mouths or wanting to return here. I would suggest Affinia hotels (the Shelburne has under $200 suites that are larger and brand new, they were booked which was why we chose the Lucerne). NOTE: although they charged us $300, if I booked this room for one night, the online cost is $290.

Mar 29 2009 	Loved this hotel!	Charming location-you feel more like a resident than a tourist. Yet restaurants and shops and Central Park close by. Our room was large, clean and well-appointed. Staff courteous and friendly. Room came with an umbrella which came in handy.

Mar 20 2009 	A Very Nice Hotel in a Great Location	Each year, to celebrate my birthday, my family drives in from Connecticut to spend a night at The Lucerne, my favorite hotel in the City. We park in the lot recommended by the hotel (note: do not exceed the 24-hour time parking time limit, or your rate jumps from $29 to $78!) and walk to the hotel after browsing the many cute shops along the way. If you have never visited the City and want to spend time in a great neighborhood removed from the touristy Times Square area, come to The Lucerne. The Upper West Side has hundreds of cute shops and great restaurants. It's family-oriented and close to Central Park, several museums, and subway stations. You can't beat the location. If you want to be in the heart of NYC, this is probably not the place for you. The hotel itself is lovely; it is small, clean, and homey; if you require luxury and many amenities, you may want to consider another property. If you will be happy with clean, tastefully decorated and slightly upscale rooms, you will love it here! We appreciated the free wi-fi. Everyone with whom we dealt, from the door man to the front desk people, was friendly and professional. If you have a double stroller as we did, be prepared to fold it to get onto one of the two tiny elevators. Our room didn't have a fridge. The rooms are a decent size for NYC; request a corner room in the back of the hotel for something slightly bigger and quieter. This was the first year we had a room that faced 79th street; it was smaller and a bit louder. Caution: if you have small children, the windows open all the way and there are no safety barriers. Also for the first time this year, we were awakened at 3:30 a.m. by drunken young men coming back to the room next to ours. They were incredibly loud coming off the elevator, and once they entered their room, we could hear them as if they were in our room. I called the front desk and, within minutes, someone came up to the their room to speak with them. I was vengeful at 7 a.m. and phoned the men to tell them to stay at a youth hostel if they were going to behave that way. We love The Lucerne and recommend it highly; we usually pay over $300 a night, and this year the rate was $220. Yeah!

Mar 15 2009 	Great value excellent service	Upper west side location in a "real" neighborhood close to good eats, small shops, bars, and most importantly Lincoln Center, Central Park and surrounding museums. Subway a short block away, if that is your preferred mode of travel. The hotel staff was outstanding, especially the concierge Liz. Rooms are tastefully decorated but nothing spectacular; they vary in size and noise level. Specify a quiet location, if available. We had a king suite on the 12th floor and rarely heard street noise. Bathrooms are small but who spends time there when in NYC? Small frig and microwave were convenient for bringing back leftovers. Also check room rates frequently. Right before we left on our trip, the internet rate dropped 25%. Would definitely stay there again and recommend to any friend or family member looking for reasonably priced hotel in an otherwise overpriced city.

Mar 4 2009 	Perfect Place for a New York Night Away from Home	I should start by saying that we visited the Lucerne at a verrry slow time of year and were pleased to get an upgrade from the very pleasant front desk staff. That set the stage for a delightful visit. Our upgraded room was spacious with a terrific view across the West Side, including a bit of the sunset on the Hudson River. The Lucerne is located on the Upper West Side, so it is not convenient for business in New York or for those planning to spend a lot of time at the theatre. It is, however, a perfect location for those on a leisure trip planning to spend time at the museums, amble about Central Park or visit one of the Citys most pleasant residential neighborhoods. And, of course, it is the perfect location for New Yorkers who want a night away from cramped apartments or a romantic evening away from home.

Mar 1 2009 	Comfortable and Upscale	The Lucerne was definitely a nice hotel. The room (two double beds) was large and spacious with a large bathroom. Probably my only complaint was that the door didn't have a tight seal on it so a lot of light and noise from the hallway leaked in.I don't know that I would spend the money myself for this hotel ($205 a night). Feb 27 2009 	Great choice for New York City hotel	My husband and I spent 5 days at the Lucerne on a leisure trip. Feb 23 2009 	Friendly clean great location!	I had a great stay at The Lucerne in Feb. 2009 --- the room was clean and comfortable and the location was unbeatable. Feb 10 2009	The Lucerne in NYC	Spent one night here in January, 2009 and had one of the best experiences ever. Lovely, clean, quiet hotel with great views from the windows. Comfortable beds, great water pressure in the shower. VERY nice desk staff...Can't wait to return!

Jan 20 2009 	Upper West Side delight	Just returned from a weekend in New York and after checking the reviews decided to stay at the Lucerne, and we are glad we did. Jan 5 2009	Great Hotel - Great Location	We spent 4 days in New York, our first trip there. The hotel was great. Very clean, nice quiet location. Jan 3 2009 	Great stay at the Lucerne	This hotel is a great find! We (2 adults & 2 children) have just returned from a 7 night stay at the Lucerne & would definately stay there again. Jan 1 2009 	Wonderful Hotel In New York City	This was a holiday to meet friends from Germany for Christmas and their travel agent had booked them at the Lucerne. Dec 17 2008 	The Lucerne Hotel was the BEST!!!	A friend suggested The Lucerne and we are so glad we decided to stay there especially since it was our very first time to NY. Nov 18 2008 	Great place!	Stayed at The Lucerne in September for 4 nights. Nov 9 2008 	Reasonable choice on the upper West Side	The Lucerne makes no attempt to make a statement or have any particular ambience -- it's simply a reasonably dependable hotel with comfortable if small rooms, about 10 blocks north of Lincoln Center. Beds, room furnishings and bathrooms are of high quality, and there are rooms on the back side which are free of street noise (though walls are thin in this older structure, so your neighbors will have something to do with how quiet your room is). Maintenance leaves something to be desired (the TV remote was nonfunctional), as does the somewhat disengaged manner at the front desk. Perhaps the least attractive aspect of the Lucerne is the dated, small lobby, which affords no real place to sit and talk with people you might want to have meet you at the hotel. Next door is a "Nice/Matin", a bright French bistro -- which is where you'll get coffee in the morning, along with nearby West Siders.

Oct 23 2008 	Comfortable Stay Great Neighborhood	We just returned from a one-week stay at the Lucerne. My husband, adult child and I stayed in a King Suite, which provided sufficient and comfortable space for all. The sitting room has a queen sized sofa that folds out into a comfortable bed; the bedroom with a very comfy king size bed. The kitchenette is a microwave and a mini-fridge and a counter with a single serve coffee pot - more than enough in a city with so many dining options.We requested a renovated room, which was nicely decorated and spotless. (I believe they are working from the lower floors up as they renovate rooms.) Front desk staff was very friendly and welcoming, checkout was quick. Concierge service excellent. Plush bathrobes in the rooms should you require them. Water pressure excellent, spotless bathroom, Temple toiletries provided, a good strong hair dryer. Your choice of New York Times or USA Today in the mornings. It was a pleasant and comfortable spot to come home to after a long day of sightseeing. We enjoyed the upper west side neighborhood, with its numerous restaurants and "neighborhoody" feel, with folks pushing strollers and walking their dogs, lots of little shops and restaurants. The subway is only one block away so we had easy access to any part of the city. It was an easy walk across Central Park in the morning to the east side museums and shopping; Central Park is only a few blocks from the hotel. Great for runners.Minor quibble: we were never left sufficient coffee pods to make three cups of coffee in the AM (single serve coffemaker). Srange since the number of occupants was obvious, and we requested extra pods on two different days (once at front desk, once via call to housekeeping). A minor problem, but when paying full rack rate for an entire week somewhat annoying.We would definitely stay here again. So much nicer than lodging in the more congested areas of the city, and a lovely hotel to boot.

Oct 15 2008 	Loved the Lucerne--again!	We were at the Lucerne for a third visit in September, and then again, overnight on the way back from Europe, two weeks later. We love the suites for longer stays, but I can recommend the queen rooms, too. Oct 14 2008 	Mixed Blessings	Weekend stay in a Non-smoking King Suite. The size of the two rooms with full bath and mini-kitchen was wonderful. Flat panel TVs in both bedroom and living room (remote did not work in the living room). Despite being on the 9th floor the street noise was unacceptable due to one of three windows having no ability to screen or filter the noise (the other two windows were better). The hotel hall ways and the room had mild, persistent ODD ODORS! The staff were subdued and while competent not friendly or in any way disposed to "go the extra mile" as on experiences at other hotels and resorts. The associated restaurant food was o.k. but rendered one of us ill in a manner that raised suspicion for food poisoning. The food was average flavor. OVERALL: NOT worth the money. Would much rather have spent the money for a known product even if added a couple of bucks to the cab rides I had to take.

Oct 7 2008 	A Wonderful Hotel on the Upper West Side	My husband and I, plus my 94-year old father-in-law recently enjoyed a great stay at the Lucerne. The location is perfect for anyone who wants to be close to Central Park, great restaurants and deli's, and eclectic shopping. It's an easy cab ride to the Theatre District and the closest subway stop is a block away. The hotel is in a lovely heritage building. The rooms are on the small side, but very comfortable and nicely furnished. My father-in-law stayed in a room equipped for people with disabilities - it met our expectations except for the lack of grab bars in the accessible shower. My husband and I were upgraded to a suite (at no extra charge) which included a little kitchenette area, a sitting area and a bedroom. Nice additional touches include your choice of newspaper in the morning and spa-quality toiletries. The staff is friendly and knowledgable. The restaurant attached to the hotel (Nice Matin) is very good - we only had breakfast there but can attest to a wide selection of well-prepared breakfast fare. We drove into Manhattan with our rental car and then dropped it off at a conveniently located Avis, just around the corner from the hotel. We picked up another rental from Avis when we left Manhattan for upstate New York.

Sep 12 2008 	truly wonderwful	My husband and I stayed in the Lucerne for 4 nights in August.The hotel is relatively small but the atmosphere is nice.We got there just around noon because we came from a cross-Atlantic flight and immigration and customs was so quick and easy and the cab driver found a quick route.The room was not ready, but they stored our luggage and allowed us to come back at 2 instead of 4 to check in.The room on the 4th floor had 2 double beds which was excellent for us. The decor of the room was really, really nice and we felt at home right away.The closet was big enough for all our suitcases and had a safe included.The bathroom had no window but a well working vent so that didn't matter. The vent turned on with the light, but you could also turn on the light without vent, so you could also be in silence.The big flat screen TV worked fine.The room was really large and had 3 chest of drawers (9 spacious drawers in total) plus a desk with desk chair. The AC worked really well, too and wasn't too noisy.There is no minibar/ fridge in the room, but signs said there is ice and vending on the 5th and 11th floor - we never used those.From the 9 hotels we stayed in on this trip this was by far the nicest.Eating is really easy, too. Unless you like French cuisine in taste and price, avoid the Nice Matin. We wanted to eat there, but a look on the menu on the side door entering the restaurant from the hotel put us off.We ate a bagel at the Ottomanelli brothers across the street - best bagels of the trip! Once we went to Times Square (Evergreen's just off of Times Square was excellent). Once we went to Mc Donalds which was the worst choice. The last day we went down to Broadway and up two blocks to the nicest restaurant which I forgot the name of.For dinner we can recommend the restaurant which must be at the corner of W 82nd and Broadway which I forgot the name of also. It is partly glass on the sidewalk, you can't miss it. They have the best American (and Jewish) food and the waiter was extremely nice. All other nights we ate in town, but nothing remarkable at that time (Ruby Tuesdays on Times Square and Dean's Second Ave near E 42nd were great at a later stay).But you will find plenty of restaurants of all tastes and bars in the area, so it is nice to just have to walk back to the hotel at night. Across the street is a small duane reade pharmacy, which provides you with snacks, drinks and other things you might have left at home. The next metro station is just down the street on the same block. Takes 1 minute in the morning and 3 at night when you walk up exhausted from the day's fun and adventure.The area felt very safe, we never encountered the slightest problem.The doormen were always at the door, but you had no security checks or such things.The housekeeping did a good job and we had a nice stay all along, including the Concierge getting us an Airport shuttle last minute and the receptionists accepting international mail at the front desk to mail for us.This is a definite "We will be back" in this hotel!

Sep 9 2008 	Great Hotel Fabulous Location	Spent a great long weekend at this lovely hotel. Rooms were tiny (typical for NYC) but were recently renovated. Sep 3 2008	Fantastic hotel!	We just returned from a 3 night stay at the Lucerne and it was absolutely perfect. We were thrilled with our decision to stay there and will most definitely return!

Aug 30 2008 	A wonderful experience - again!	Our family of 4 with 2 children ages 5 and 8 stayed at the Lucerne in August for 2 nights. Aug 5 2008 	Solid choice	The Lucerne is a fairly small 13-story Manhattan hotel on the upper west side. We had a small suite with two queen beds and a sitting room with sofa bed, micro-wave, refrig, toaster etc. The decor was not trendy but very clean and well maintained, with good mattresses, linens, robes etc. The staff was really the highlight - front desk totally service-oriented, good security, excellent concierges. It's unfathomable why anyone would choose to stay in the Midtown theater district. The hotel is only a few blocks from Central Park, a few blocks the other way from the Hudson River, a nice walk to Lincoln Center - and around the corner from Zabar's and H&H Bagel!!! The rooms are all very nice - BUT they do vary considerably in size. The first time I stayed (with my wife and 2 sons), the room was pretty cramped. Last month (July 2007) the room on a higher floor was huge - by NYC standards.The attached restaurant, Nice Matin, is pretty good, but with so many restaurant choices nearby, a bit superfluous.

Aug 22 2007 	Location can't be beat	We are a family with 2 teenagers so a spacious room was a priority. We stayed in the king suite and it was perfect for us. The air conditioner worked great. The toilet handle was tricky, you just have to push down hard. The location, the upper west side, was super -- the hotel is surrounded by restaurants, many of which offer outdoor dining. There are grocery stores, drug stores, a department store and small shops all around the area. The Lucerne is one block from the 1,2,3 line. We went all around Manhattan and it was so nice to come back to the relative quiet of this part of NYC. The hotel staff is very nice. The business center is undergoing renovation so we could not use its computers but the front desk did print out some documents for us at our request. We booked tickets to the Museum of Natural History through the concierge and she was very helpful and even alerted us that the subway schedule changes on the weekend. Aug 20 2007 	Loved the Lucerne - Great for Families!	The Lucerne is a lovely, small boutique hotel on the Upper West Side two blocks from Central Park and the Museum of Natural History. The rest of the hotel staff was wonderful. We stayed for over a week and couldn't have been happier. The Nice Matin next door is great for a late night dinner after a show.

Aug 19 2007	Highly Recommend the Lucerne	We read the reviews on Trip Advisor for this hotel before booking and it certainly lived up to the praise! Aug 16 2007 	New York Hotel Highlight	The hotel really lives up to the description on it's own website. The whole area has plenty of good restuarants though more for adults and older children than little ones.Whilst seemingly out of the madness of NYC it is easily accessible by Subway (end of the street - 10 mins to Times Square), by Bus (outside the door - 15 mins to 5th Avenue) and of course by Yellow Cab. Aug 11 2007 	Lucerne was okay	Just got back from a weeks stay at the Lucerne. Everyone from the doorman to the front desk was very nice. I had booked a double queen suite and asked for a quiet room on arrival. Now the front desk did offer to move us but since it meant repacking everything( I had unpacked everything since it was so quiet on Sun.) we decided to stay put. . We were usually out of the room during the day and the work stopped at 5pm. Just wish we had been informed before hand that there was construction. The beds were very comfortable, we all slept great. Air conditioner worked very well. Had no problems w the internet service. The sitting room was quite small and only had 2 chairs. The bathroom was small but not tiny. The location can't be beat- close to subway, lots of restaurants and I felt very safe. I would stay again but would make sure that my room was not near any renovations

Aug 10 2007 	Great place at a reasonable price close to subway	My daughter and I just got back from an overnight shopping trip in NYC and found this reasonable hotel recommended by TripAdvisor reviewers. It seems like all our other favorite hotels are up to $450 a night and we just did not want to shell out that much. With tax, our room at the Lucerne was $298 and just fine. We liked it very much. The room was clean and comfortable and very convenient to the subway. Our ninth floor double queen room was quiet (!) and beds comfortable. The adjoining restaurant was very nice. It's a great alternative to the fluffy robe and minibar type hotel.

Aug 7 2007 	Great Hotel for a Great Price	We loved our stay at the Lucerne. We arrived early (11am) and they had a room available for us to check-in to, which was great. The room was beautifully decorated. Not huge, but adequate for ourselves and teeenage son, and hey this is New York. The bedsheets were changed everyday, if you require them to be done, and Fresh toiletries and towels put out. Small charge applies to use the business internet room but it is very handy to check on flights etc. Lady in reception very helpful and will book theatre tickets and provide advice on where to eat etc. She also confirmed our Shuttle Bus for our return to JFK.Couldn't fault the hotel and would definitely recommend to friends.The location on the Upper West side we found great. Away from the hustle and bustle of Mid and Down Town - which were a short and convenient underground journey away. Also short walk to Central Park.The area around the Lucerne is fairly residential, with lots of restaurants and bars. No shortage of choice. Also if you turn right out of the hotel, and walk down to the Hudson River, there is a fantastic bar/restaurant, with great atmosphere, down by the river - well worth walking down to, to watch the sun go down.We had a fantastic stay in New York and would recommend the ferry to Liberty Island and Ellis Island (hire the headphones, well worth it). Aug 4 2007 	Perfect Choice	The Lucerne turned out to be the perfect choice for my four day stay in Manhattan. The staff was extremely pleasant and helpful. Above all, I truly enjoyed the accommodations. I am a light and restless sleeper, and fret about that at every hotel I stay. Yet I slept soundly every night with no disturbances of any kind. The room was big enough for the solo traveler (and two people would also be very comfortable). The bed and bathroom were of great quality, and the AC kept the room as chilly as I desired. Had a view of the Hudson (took a photo of the big red sun setting over the river from my window).Conveniently located in the Upper West side, I walked everywhere each day: one block from the Museum of Natural History, two blocks from Central Park, seven blocks from Strawberry Fields and the Imagine mosaic; an easy stroll across the park to the Met, Frick, Guggenheim. I even walked through the park to midtown sites as well (Radio City, Rockfeller Center, MoMA). Broadway is also only a block away. The cab ride from and to Penn Station was effortless and inexpensive. I enjoyed a delicious and relaxing dinner every evening at restaurants only a block or two from the hotel (and a nice breakfast at the hotel restaurant, Nice Matin).Some sites give the Lucerne 2 stars, others 3. I would gladly award it 3 stars; I have stayed in many US cities at hotels claiming to be 3 stars and mostly have been disappointed. For New York, the price was a good deal (I booked end of July-early Aug). I plan to make the Lucerne my regular hotel for all future visits. I commend the management and staff.

Aug 3 2007	Great location!	We were pleasantly surprised by this wonderful gem of a hotel. We have been to New York before and stayed at a hotel near the kaos of Time Square. The Lucerne was definitey a better choice. The Lucerne was clean, very comfortable and close to great restaurants, subway, Central Park, Museums, and Riverside Park. It was pleasure coming home in the evening after a hectic day of sightseeing. The staff was friendly and very helpful. The Lucerne would certainly be the choice of hotel the next time we visit New York.

Aug 2 2007 	Sublime Relaxation Retreat while in town for the NY Bar Exam	In town to take the the New York Bar Exam, I wanted a quiet retreat where I could get some quality sleep, relax, be close to transportation, and be far away from honking horns, frantic tourists while enjoying some local flavors. I got all of these things from my stay at The Lucerne, and at a great bargain of a price! There is impeccable customer service here--hotel porters, elevator operators, front desk, cleaning service--all very polite and helpful, but also easily avoidable if you are feeling anti-social or particularly independent (e.g., don't need someone to hail you a cab). I got the smallest cheapest room, and I was wowed by the size of the room and bathroom (huge for Manhattan!). Very clean, and luxurious. Flat screen TV, plush pillows. Courtesy umbrella in the closet came in handy. Combination safe in room. In my dazed and confused state after taking the 2-day bar exam, I ended up having a major crisis after I had already checked out and left town. I called the hotel and spoke to the manager (Dexter), who was extremely courteous and helpful, and resolved my dilemma with the utmost care. Food - Nice Matin, the restaurant next door, is OK, but a bit pricey, even with the hotel discount, and better food can be had all along Broadway or Amsterdam within walking distance. You can take 10 steps further from Nice Matin and have a world of options at your fingertips. Zabar's is right down the block on Broadway. Tasty local eats less than a 2-minute walk away on Amsterdam abound (Chinese, Indian, diners, South American, fusion, etc). Necessities - Duane Reede right across the streetTransportation - 1 Train is very close (this was a major factor for me, as I hate walking more than 1 long block and 1.5 short blocks to the subway); taxis on Broadway or Amsterdam readily hailableAlso, there are a bunch of stores on Broadway, if you have some time to kill - Filene's Basement, Sephora, Staples, etc. Cons - wireless internet is not free (but is only about $5.95 for entire duration of stay). Business Center is a rip-off (something like 30cents/min to get online). Restaurants listed in the hotel guide provided in the room are a poor representation of what is really available right outside the hotel! Toiletries were exceptionally odiferous and a bit masculine in scent.

Jul 31 2007 	Great hotel	Friendly, clean, quiet, lovely, convenient. Great NY Hotel. Very convenient to subway. . Would definetly stay again. Only complaints are the pillows are very uncomfortable and lumpy and could not get extra set of sheets although I had asked for three days in a row.

Jul 23 2007 	Great hotel and location !	Hotel was excellent. Jul 1 2007 	What a dump!	We chose this hotel because of the location (we have family on the upper west side), and we were somewhat hopeful given the reviews we read. Jun 25 2007	Great Place!	No problems at all. Room was larger than I expected because everyone always talks about NYC having small rooms. The Conceierge (Liz) was very helpful. Jun 2 2007 	Great experience	This hotel was selected for me for a conference I attended. I found it very pleasant. I had a single room with a queen bed. It was well decorated and the bathroom was lovely. The amenities (bed, pillows, towels, TV, etc.) were slightly above average. The location was excellent, a two block walk to Central Park, a block from Zabar's, with many good eateries in the area. The staff were noticeably pleasant and attentive. Jun 1 2007 	Comfortable Cozy and Great Value	I would just like to add my praise for this hotel along with the rest written here.My husband and I stayed here for 3 nights in the end of May 2007.As neither of us had ever travelled to NYC before, we were keen to find somewhere to stay that was clean, comfortable, convenient, safe, and not too straining on the budget.We stumbled upon this hotel whilst surfing the net and thought it sounded too good to be true, however, after reading multiple reviews on this site we decided to go ahead and book.We were not disappointed in the slightest. In fact, we were thrilled.We found the Lucerne to be everything it promised.We stayed in a superior queen room and, although it was fairly small, it was well laid out and functional. The furnishings chosen for the room were elegant and made us feel like we were staying in a much more expensive hotel. We were on the 11th floor. Traffic noise was present but bearable however, the room had the tendency to get quite hot if the air conditioner was not turned on (even when the outside air temp was not particularly hot).All staff were friendly and helpful and sounded as though they knew exactly what they were doing (I know this is what you would always hope for, however, in my experience it is unfortunately not terribly common). At some points they went above and beyond the call of duty (eg the bell boy took the time to explain to us the ins and outs of how Manhattan was laid out and how the streets were named without being asked... invaluable abvice!)We found its proximity to the subway to be terrific - very easy to get around anywhere and everywhere we wanted to go.Good concierge service, although we did find ourselves being talked into spending a bit more money than what we had planned for city tours etc (mind you, these were well worth the money...would thoroughly recommend the double decker sight seeing hop on, hop off busses for anyone who has never been to NYC before and wants to see everything there is to see in a short amount of time).We utilised the wireless internet service which was good for us and not terribly expensive (although, beware, once you have used it you will be billed per night for the rest of your stay, so if you were only planning on using it for one quick time on the first night of your week long stay and then not again, this could get quite expensive).All in all we were extremely happy with everything about our stay at the Lucerne and would have no hesitations recommending it to others or, if we ever return, staying there again.

May 28 2007	Great location quiet hotel	If you need lodging on the upper westside of New York, this is a great hotel in a great location. The subway stop is at the end of the block. There are lots of restaurants nearby. The location is between Central Park and Riverside Park if you want a nice place to walk or for the kids to play. We had a room with two double beds that was a good size. It was not the tiny room you get so often in NYC. And it was quiet! We had a corner room but traffic and city noise was not a problem. We barely heard people in the hall or neighboring rooms. We did not eat at the restaruant but it looked very nice and always had a good crowd. The staff was very courteous and attentive. It was pricey but still less than other hotels we considered in the same area. Every hotel seemed to go up in time for college graduations!

May 20 2007 	An elegant mid-budget choice	This is an elegant little hotel. My room on the 12th floor looked like it had been recently renovated. It looked out over Amsterdam Avenue (at the back of the hotel), but because it was so high up, I wasn't bothered by noise. Natural light filled the room, and even though it wasn't large, it felt airy.The attached restaurant, Nice Matin, seems popular with the locals. Hotel guests can access it straight from the lobby. I had both dinner and breakfast there and was not disappointed. I didn't get to try the other neighborhood restaurants, but there seems to be no shortage of good places to eat.This is not a budget hotel, but neither is it overpriced for what you get. May 9 2007 	I hate hotels that lie to me	So I'm staying here at the Lucerne, which is a reasonably nice hotel for New York. The rooms are small but comfortable. A guy comes up, fiddles with it, and it works. For 2 minutes. Then it goes off and never comes back on, and the room is sweltering all night.The next morning I ask the desk to fix the AC, and the desk clerk gives me some complete load of hooey about how the water tank on the roof has been drained and there's no AC in the building. I tell him that I had AC for two minutes last night and he's completely bulls***ing me.Same thing last night. The maintenance guy comes in, says only turn it to cold 3/4 of the way, and then it'll be fine. Nope, 2 minutes later it goes off and never comes back on.Now I've got ANOTHER maintence guy here. He says everything is fine. But it isn't as my room is 85 degrees.What a load of junk. I would love this hotel, if they didn't lie to me, and if they could figure out how to fix their air conditioning.

May 7 2007 	Totally Miranda!	The Lucerne is a beautiful property, in a great location, with friendly, helpful people. I recommend it highly. I had never stayed on the Upper West Side. I usually stay mid-town, but my last experience (at the Warwick) was so deafeningly loud I decided to try something new. It was totally Miranda (as is Sex in the City)! The Upper West Side is a completely different experience!The Lucerne is a find. And I'm glad I found it.I spent 9 days in room 815. My room was not large but completely remodeled with a flat screen TV and a good size writing desk. The bed was very comfortable. The window opened. The bathroom was enormous. Everything was clean, clean, clean. The housekeeper was very attentive. The bellman were very helpful. The 8th floor is beingrenovated so there was a little construction noise but it was limitedto after 9 am (time to get up!) and everyone went home at 5 pm so thenights were very quiet.The only negative experience I had was with the room service. It wasn't the price of the hamburger that offended me and it came fairly fast. It was the quality. One of the worst burger's I've ever had. Bland, undercooked and generally bad. And the fries were even worse. Not good.The property itself is a block away from one subway line (1,2 & 3) and three blocks from a completely different line (A, B, C & D). The crosstown bus (the one that takes you to the Met) is across the street. Public transportation in New York has come a long way - I never once took a cab - buses and subway all the way.I had a great trip - I'd recommend the Lucerne to everyone. Apr 4 2007 	Great place to stay	My daughter and I stayed at the Lucerne, for our first visit to NY. We found our recently renovated room to be big enough for us and very modern. There was a flat screen tv, and the bathoom was spotless. There was no noise from outside at night, but some renovation noise during the day. Ask for a room on a floor that has completed the makeover. The staff and doormen were very friendly and helpful. We did not understand the subway and each morning the conceirge would write down our travel plans and guide us to where we were going. Since the stop is just on the corner, coming back late at night was not a problem. This help greatly! There are great restaurants in the neighborhood and we felt very safe. The Ocean Grill at the end of the street had outdoor seating and awsome seafood. There is a drugstore acroos the street for all the things you forgot, including snacks for your room. We will return to NY and stay here again.

Mar 7 2007 	Upper West Side in the middle of the action	I would up at The Lucerne at the last minute after a booking problem with another hotel. Therefore, I probably paid top dollar for my room, and that may have clouded the experience. The room was adequate, but I feel like I could have done better for $300 a night. Maybe I also couldn't help but think that when I used to live in this neighborhood The Lucerne was a women's residence for Barnard's College. In any event, it is certainly nicer than a dorm, and if the rooms are basic hotel-modern, the building itself has retained most of its early 20th century architectural character. (The deep red stone exterior is actually quite lovely.) Assessing the location would depend on your priorities. This slice of the Upper West Side is chock full of restaurants at all price levels, and many bars that attract a young and boisterous weekend drinking crowd. With that in mind, if you are sensitive to noise you might want to request a room that does not face either 79th Street or Amsterdam Avenue, particularly on the weekend and particularly in nice weather, when the drinkers can hang out on the street until 2 or 3 in the morning. The Lucerne does present a convenient location in terms of the subway (at the end of the street) and proximity to some great New York speciality shops (especially food). The Upper West Side is a vibrant and diverse neighborhood, and you also have the advantage, in warm weather, of proximity to both Riverside and Central Parks. In sum, The Lucerne is a decent choice, but if I wanted to stay in this neighborhood I would first look at The Excelsior, which is closer to Central Park, facing The Museum of Natural History. My experience with The Excelsior is also that it's better bang for the buck. But as I said, in all fairness, I did not have the opportunity to "shop rates" at The Lucerne.

Mar 1 2007	Excellent stay at the Lucerne	My wife and I spent one evening at the Lucerne in mid-February while we were in town for her birthday. We got a room with one king bed on the tenth floor. It had been very recently renovated, in a tan and gold scheme with french-style furniture with marble tops. The room was quiet, very comfortable, and, while hardly huge, had plenty of space. The staff was courteous, warm and professional. The location is perfect for access to the upper west side and the park. I will definitely stay there the next time I need a place in the neighborhood. Our stay was beyond expectations.

Jan 16 2007 	Quite Comfortable	My husband and I just returned from 3 nights at the Lucerne and overall it was comfortable, clean and sufficed perfectly for our needs. In these non-suite rooms your bed is directly next to the entry door, and this door is not well isolated and has cracks. As a result, disturbing light comes in from the corridor, plus the noise. There's also street noise, due to the fact that the sliding windows don't close well. But after the first night I got used to it and had a decent sleep. Big thumbs up for the personnel that does everything to help you and make you feel at ease. This time we skipped the adjoining Nice Matin restaurant, but had our breakfasts at New Wave, nearby on Broadway. It's a small wonderful neighbourhood diner with very friendly waittresses. All the times we were there they played old Stevie Wonder songs and it all just fitted right. In the area there are many good local restaurants, it's always difficult to make a pick and you wish you could eat 7 times a day.Can't wait to be back.

Dec 19 2006 	Hotel Lucerne	This is really a great hotel - clean, efficient, comfortable. Great location too, 3 blocks from Central Park & a really nice residential area with lots of restaurants & bars around (EJ's luncheonette around the corner does great breakfasts, shakes, burgers etc!)This is ideal if you want to escape the mad, busy tourist areas of NYC & recharge your batteries in the evening, but a Subway station is just at the end of the block to reach places really easily.Great stay & will definately stay there again.

Dec 6 2006 	Give Lucerne a try.. Nice for the money	Great Location, Friendly Staff, room itself was larger then expected for NYC hotels. Only down-side needed new carpet yesterday. Nov 26 2006 	Good all round	Location was great, bus stop directly across the street and subway close by. Lots of restaurants close by (can recommend Sarabeth's). Nov 25 2006	Wonderful hotel still talking about our stay!	Recently stayed at the Lucerne Hotel on the upper west side. Every staff member was extremely friendly and helpful. Nov 16 2006 	Loved the Lucerne	I've been to NYC about 3 or 4 times on business in the last year and grew tired of staying in crowded Midtown, so I decided to stay in a different area this time. I learned about the Lucerne on ------.com and chose to stay at the hotel after reading all of the positive reviews on tripadvisor. Nov 16 2006 	Very comfortable and clean	We lived in this area for around 25 years, having left for California around 14 years ago, and still come back to visit regularly. My last remaining friend in the area, whose apartment we used to stay at, just sold his home to leave the city. So, we decided to stay at this hotel on our old home turf to do a business and pleasure tip to NYC.It's a very nice place, reasonably well kept with a few touches of class in terms of cleanliness, style, lobby, staff, a very nice litte gym, excellent service, robes, umbrella in the room, good beds, good pillows, free New York Times (or USA Today) every morning (even Sunday Times!), and a good wireless internet service for a flat fee per stay. I would recommend the hotel to others and probably stay there again. I should explain that this building is on the northwest corner of 79th Street and Amsterdam Avenue and is in one of the best non-touristy residential areas of Manhattan -- referred to as the "upper west side". Two sides of the building face the street, and the other two sides abut adjacent buildings. We stayed in a suite on the ninth floor (there are twelve plus penthouse) with two queen beds that faced 79th Street. It was noiser than the inner sides of the building (north and west facing), but since it faced south, it got a good deal of sun. Since I'm from New York, the traffic noise -- cut down signifcantly by the good windows (which you can open, by the way) -- didn't bother us at all. Because they originally offered us a room on the fifth floor facing west, I can tell you that I noticed that if you are facing west, you must be on the 6th floor or above or you will be facing a dark light well. That side will, however be quieter.The stay was not without minor problems. So, just to list them: 1) Drinking glasses were not always replaced with clean ones, 2) The suite had insufficient workspace so that even though it had a little kitchenette, there was really no good place for two people to sit and eat. There was only one desk chair in the sitting room (and also a loveseat and a TV), so we could not both sit at the little desk. We tried to bring a small easychair in from the bedroom, but it wouldn't fit through the doorway. I suppose we could have asked for anther desk chair, but we didn't. 3) Both TV remotes (there were two TVs in this suite) needed new batteries that could not be replaced by a guest (unless the guest happened to be packing a set of Alan wrenches). We called to have the batteries replaced ($5 tip) but thought it was a little suspicious in the first place, since both remotes were bad. We particularly thought it suspicious when the guy they sent with two new remotes received another call while he was servicing our room, about another room that need new remotes. The service was very fast, however. 4) There was a fridge in the room that wasn't working; but they quickly replaced it from their stash of (as I was told by one staff member) around 20 spare fridges. Another $5 tip to reward very fast service. But hmmm. 5) We took the flat rate option for wireless internet service ($11.95, I believe) that covered our whole stay, but it incorrectly expired twice. The hotel did make good on their promise to keep it a flat rate; but we had to go through the hassle of setting the account up again both times it expired. And of course, things like that always stop working when you can least afford the time!So, despite our little list of problems (and we are nitpickers who can find problems in pretty much >any< hotel), we thought they were were all reasonably small and manageable. Thus the basic recommendation holds.

Nov 13 2006 	Nice place - had a great time	Found the Lucerne on TripAdvisor and liked the look of it, so my brother and I booked in for four nights in September 2005.Using it as a home base we ventured out by foot to all points of interest between Central Park and Battery Park, including Ground Zero, Empire State Building, Wall Street etc etc, and let me tell you - next time we rent a car. It was a long, long walk even for two fit young guys, so plan ahead if you're older or infirm.The area is great at night, with a huge selection of places to eat and drink, from sports bars to themed restaurants etc. There is also a convenience store across the street for all your needs. The staff are friendly, the place is clean as a whistle, and the room was a perfect size ( two double beds, bathroom, tv, coffee maker)The only problem we had was a lack of a fridge, but there was cold beer to be had up and down Amsterdam, so it wasn't a drama. Great place and we plan on returning March 07.

Nov 7 2006 	An elegant hotel in a thriving neighbourhoor	We stayed here over NYC marathon weekend but you couldn't tell from the staff that they were probably stretched to capacity.A faultless check-in on the Thursday coincided with complementary afternoon tea (OK so it was Earl Grey in plastic beakers but they were really trying!) All the front of house staff were civility itself. The hotel is a little off the tourist track for things like the big 5 Ave shops but absolutely great for Central Park, the Lincoln Centre and the Natural History Museum. The room (a double Queen on the 11th floor) was big enough for the three adults staying and was serviced every day by housekeeping.The fact it's off the beaten track is one of its more redeeming features as you don't feel that the restaurants around the place are only after the tourist $. And downtown is only a cab or a convenient subway ride away. Local restaurant recommendations would be Sarabeth across the street, EJ diner just two blocks up or a fantastic bakery just a little further up Amsterdam serving all organic produce.The hotel also laid on pre-marathon snacks as we left early on the Sunday morning which showed their attention to their guests. One word of warning though if you're on a budget allow for the myriad of NY taxes on top of the room rate, occupancy, tourist and sales tax added a further $200 to our final 4 night bill.

Oct 24 2006 	A great family neighbouhood	We have just returned from a four night stay at the The Lucerne hotel. We stayed in a double superior room with our two children aged seven and ten. The hotel was excellent, the staff were very helpful and friendly ,the room size was adequate for us especially as all we did was sleep there. The best part of the Lucerne was it's location we loved the UWS especially Amsterdam Ave - so many shops and restaurants .Our children felt really at home and it was nice to see the local children coming and going to school. Fantastic breakfasts at Good Enough To Eat and EJ's.For a quick cheap and typical New York breakfast try Zabars. The subway was only two minutes walk away or you can walk to to central park, natural history museum or Columbus circle if you want take in more of the city . The planatarium in the Rose space center was the highlight of our trip.The only negative of the trip was the Jekyll and Hyde club on Sixth Ave,the food was expensive and poor quality and the entertainment was rubbish.We would definitely stay at the Lucerne again.

Oct 18 2006	great stay wished it was less expensive	From Chicago.Stayed Columbus Day weekend. We did a lot of research on this website and others. Narrowed down to Lucerne or Affinia Manhattan. Affinia Manhattan was $50 less a night. But went with Lucerne because we felt the neighborhood feel and proximity to Central Park made it $50 better.I think we were right.We payed avg of $350/night for 4 nights. This seemed very expensive but was par for the course as we checked other hotels.Overall great stay. We (wife and I) stayed in the standard (small) Queen room. Everything was very clean and in very good condition. Staff was very helpful and very polite.Our first room had only a view of the brick wall of the building next to us. I called front desk and asked for a better room. Reception needed a few minutes to check for available room. Called back a few minutes later with a better room. Bellhop came to our room with new keys and took our bags to the other room. Great service. This room was on the 6th floor overlooking Amsterdam Av.Bathroom was very clean and maid service did a fine job.Went to Nice Matin (attached restaurant) for breakfast one morning with the 20% off hotel coupon. Excellent breakfast. Looked like a lot of locals were there.The neighborhood is the upper west side and has got a very busy, tight feel to it. A lot of small business and restuarants lining Amsterdam and Broadway. Though based on other reviews of the area I expected the area to be more upscale. I didn't get that impression at all. Kind of dirty (much the same as all of NYC). The area is pretty lively late night. Restaurants and bars are active. But only a 10 min walk to the Park. 3 min walk to Subway.Would stay here again unless I found I real good deal elsewhere.Would have given it 5 stars if it was a little less expensive.

Oct 13 2006 	Great Stay	This is a top notch hotel. The location can not be beat. Upper West side, 79th and Amsterdam.Busy all the time, in the area, but the hotel was calm and spotless. More areas to eat than I can list. We had dinner at the ocean grill , 78th and Columbus, one block over, Tremendous dinner and well presented. I had Tuna grilled that was out of the world. We also ate at Coppolos, across the street from the hotel. Great Italian. The subway stop is one block over at 79th and Broadway. Very safe and easy to figure out with a map. No need to stay near Times square.Breakfast is easy, there is a coffee shop on every corner.And i usually got coffee and rolls/muffins , at world coffee , Columbus and 80th. I did not have any bad coffee during my stay. Everything you need is within walking dsistance. You will not believe the choices available. We have stayed near Times Square in the past, but this is my new favorite place to stay. My one complaint is that the room is a bit small, but we were only able to book a double, the hotel was full.

Sep 19 2006 	Great Stay	We stayed three nights at The Lucerne Hotel from Aug. 15 - 18th (room 1223). The room was much bigger than we anticipated and was very clean. My husband, two teenage boys and myself had enough room and did not feel cramped at all. The beds were real comfortable, maybe too comfortable as we slept in later than we planned to each day.Across the street was a good deli for breakfast and also an Italian restaurant that was good and reasonably priced. It wasa couple of blocks to the subway which we found convenient.The staff was very friendly and accomodating. We are hoping to go back next year and we would definitely stay here again. Aug 8 2006	Wonderful	We stay at the Lucerne whenever we are in New York. Wadsworth, Tampa, FL

Jul 24 2006 	Great neighborhood very nice hotel	I have been going to NYC for years, but had particular needs on this trip that were met by the Lucerne for a good price. It's a very distinctive old building in a great location about 5- 10 mins stroll from various subway lines and 10 mins walk to the park. The double room we had (1010) was a corner room with nice views of 79th and Amsterdam. Decent bathroom and above average beds (I am picky about that). Pleasant staff, pretty lobby and chic restaurant downstairs. I chose it mainly for the neighborhood and two of my favorite NYC restuarants: Sarabeth's and Isabella's. There are so many great restaurants to try in the area and Zabar's is just down the street. It's a must, as is H&H for the best bagels in Manhattan. Both places are near 80th st on Broadway.One special note: They have ragingly good air conditioning in summer! We were kept very cool on the hottest week of the year thus far.I'd happily stay there again and recommend it to my picky parents,

Jul 23 2006 	Good choice for our first visit to NYC	We chose the Lucerne based on Trip Advisor reviews for our family's first-ever visit to NYC and it was a good choice. Our stay was for 3 nights in July, 2006. The hotel was clean and we found both the desk staff and bellhops to be very friendly and helpful. The neighbourhood appears safe and clean. There are subway stations within a few blocks that took us to Yankee Stadium, the Broadway Theatre District, Statue of Liberty, etc. The Nice/Matin restaurant downstairs was good and there is a sufficient choice of other restaurants nearby, plus a handy 24-hour drug store across the street. The only negative comments we would make are that the rooms are small (normal for NYC I'm sure), there was a fair amount of street noise coming through the closed window (again, has to be normal for most any NYC hotel) and when it was time to leave for the train station the bellhop had about a 15 minute struggle trying to flag down a cab - for some reason it doesn't appear cabs want to take fares from the Lucerne, so plan to leave a little early if you want to take a cab. We would definitely stay at the Lucerne if we visited NYC again, especially since it is situated in a quieter, more residential neighbourhood than farther south in Manhattan.

Jul 9 2006	Good place to stay	Having read the reviews of the Lucerne on TripAdvisor, we decided to book here. Overall the hotel is good and there were minor problems (which seemed to occur on a daily basis) during our stay but these were immediately rectified by the friendly staff. Such problems included a leak in our initial room that we were given, a tempramental TV and a lack of hot water one morning (which seemed to be a central boiler problem). As I say these problems were immediately tended to on reporting and the staff were very courteous which made a lot of difference.Our room was clean, of a good size and quiet. Room service was good even in the early hours of the morning and the tourism desk in the lobby was very helpful (although chairs at its desk wouldn't go amiss!).The location of the hotel is good for getting away from the crowds at Times Square and if you feel brave the '1' subway station is virtually opposite the hotel. We chose to take taxis around which can work out expensive with tips etc. Good local restaurants are abundant around the hotel although we didn't have a chance to visit Nice Matin.Overall we would probably stay there again if the rates were as comparitively good as we managed this time.
